Inc. is to produce and distribute ice. To conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 30,850 pounds 
piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) to provide refrigeration for the production and distribution of ice. Typical operating conditions range from 10 psig on the low-pressure side of the system to 180 psig on the high side. Like a household refrigerator, there are no expected leaks or releases of ammonia from the refrigeration system at Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc., which is a closed-loop system.

High pressure liquid from the High-Pressure Receiver is supplied to the Flash Economizer. From the Flash Economizer, the ammonia is fed to the -10°F and +10°F Recirculated Liquid Recirculation Packages. The -10°F Recirculated Liquid Recirculation Package RRP-2 supplies sub-cooled liquid ammonia to Evaporators E-1 to E-16, and then the 'wet suction' (liquid/vapor mix) ammonia is sent back to the -10°F Recirculated Liquid Recirculation Package RRP-2. The liquid settles to the bottom and the vapor rises to the top and is drawn off by Compressors C-3, C-4, and C-5. The +10°F Recirculated Liquid Recirculation Package RRP-1 supplies sub-cooled liquid ammonia to the Ice Machines and receives ammonia vapor/liquid mix from the Ice Machines. In the RRP-1, liquid settles to the bottom and vapor rises to the top and is drawn by Compressors C-1, C-2, C-3, C-4, and C-6. From the compressors, the ammonia vapor is discharged to the Evaporative Condensers, Evaporators E-1 to E-16, and Ice Machines. The Heat Exchanger receives high stage discharge from Compressors C-1 - C-6 and discharges high pressure liquid to the High-Pressure Receiver. The ammonia leaving the Evaporative Condensers is high pressure liquid which gravity flows into the

All process equipment and piping are designed according to ASME standards. All ASME vessels and compressors are equipped with pressure relief valves which are set to actuate at 250 psig except for the pressure relief valves on the oil pots, oil separator on the compressors, and Evaporative Condensers which actuate at 300 psig. All relief valves except for the relief valve on the evaporative condensers are tied to a common header that vent to the Ammonia Diffusion Tank.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Arctic Glacier is second to none. Our water filtration and purification systems exceed all national and international standards delivering to you the highest quality ice product available.

On March 1, 2007, Arctic Glacier Inc. acquired the assets and operations of The Union Ice Company.

Arctic Glacier Income Fund, through its wholly owned operating company, Arctic Glacier Inc., is a leading producer, marketer, and distributor of high-quality packaged ice to consumers in Canada and the United States, primarily under the brand name of Arctic Glacier; Premium Ice. Arctic Glacier operates 39 production plants and 48 distribution facilities across Canada and the northeastern, central and western United States servicing more than 75,000 retail accounts. Arctic Glacier also licenses its tr

ade names and proprietary technology to independently owned companies in Canada and the United States under franchise and license agreements.

The Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc.'s safety and environmental policies are administered by the Senior Plant Manager with the assistance of the Chief Engineer, who conducts periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the PSM/RMP/CalARP Program. 

Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. is a "non-responding" facility. The facility's Emergency Coordinators (Chief Engineer, Regional Manager, and/or Senior Plant Manager) have discussed an emergency action plan with the City of Los Angeles County Fire Department (Incident Commander). In an emergency (ammonia release), the Emergency Coordinator role is to alert employees of an evacuation and to ensure all employees and visitors/contractors have exited the building safely. The Emergency Coordinator immediately calls 911 while waiting for City of Los Angeles County Fire Department to arrive at the scene. The rest of the employees are to be evacuated from the facility to a designated area. The contact information for the Emergency Coordinators and agencies are detailed in the Arctic Glacier Vernon Facility's Emergency Action Plan included in this Program.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. facility is located at 2970 East 50th Street in Vernon, California, which is located approximately 3.6 miles east of Interstate 110, 3.2 miles west of Interstate 710, and 2 miles south of Interstate 5. The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban. The facility was constructed and began operations in 2006.

For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits. Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled. The facility also utilizes fixed ammonia leak detectors to alert personnel of a possible ammonia leak, to call the fire department when the concentration has reached 25 ppm, and to shut down the system at 10,000 ppm. Pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels protect the equipment from over pressurization.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The CalARP Program defines "accident" as the following:

"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.
The release must have caused at least one of the following:

	On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (19CCR2750.9(a)); or
	Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (19CCR2750.9(a))."
Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history, there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or that meet the criteria above in the last five years (July 2016-Jan 2023).
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect. This plan was designed to meet the following objectives:
	save lives.
	minimize and avoid injuries.
	protect the environment; and
	minimize property damage.

The plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This plan is reviewed and updated at least

once per year. This plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations.

Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system. If an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger and the supervisor. The supervisor then notifies the Regional Manager/Senior Plant Manager/Chief Engineer/designee who will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem. Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Three-Year Compliance Audit was performed on August 9, 2019. The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Revalidation was performed on July 28, 2021to satisfy the five-year update requirements. The status of the recommendations resulting from the previous Process Hazard Analysis (2016) was reviewed during the PHA Revalidation study. The 2019 Three-Year Compliance Audit and the 2021 Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation studies generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. facility located in Vernon, California. The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures. The Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. safety committee is planning to complete several items, including all outstanding and new recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. These changes include the following items:

1.	Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.
2.	Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.
3.	Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.
4.	Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and impl

ement changes as needed.

EXTERNAL EVENTS

External events were considered during the HAZOP as any type of catastrophic failure (i.e., line break). Catastrophic failures encompass the following external events: meteorite impact, missile impact, sabotage, and war. A catastrophic line failure of the ammonia system could result in a line break, which was examined in the Hazard Assessment.
